Comment: Your emotional rant has nothing to do with science, but more with backwoods bias and beliefs.
Geneticist Ste Rikhardsson:
"The word “gender” is from the French word “genre” which means “type, class, kind”.Gender is a psychological construct whereas sex is a physical entity. The word “gender” is used wrongly by most people as a synonym for sex mainly because for 99% of people in the world, the two are the same. But just because they are the same for you, it doesn’t mean it is the same for everyone.
Even though there are two MAIN sexes, there are at least 16 types of sexes among humans. Many of these people are classed as “intersex”. Some people are born with XXY chromosomes or other combinations as well as ambiguous sex organs (sometimes totally ambiguous, sometimes with breasts and a penis, sometimes with a vagina, womb and flat chest, and sometimes with working or non-working sexual organs)."
This isn't "garbage," as you suggest. People are different. Differences should be respected.

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: I think the judge messed up here:

"The interests of the accused in having a fair trial where the accused is able to make full answer and defence outweighs the public interest in protecting police-investigative techniques."

Hello?

Why should folks accused in court be told in detail exactly how it was that their phone messages were intercepted? Why?

Look, consider the following regarding the case in question (and lets call it "gamma-zeta technique"):

1. The police sought and received appropriate warrants before using the gamma-zeta technique against the suspects.
2. The courtroom could have read out the intercepted messages and plainly asked the accused if the message was real or not - there was no need to have anyone explain how the gamma-zeta technique works.
3. The courtroom could have asked the technology expert of the phone company and cops if the message, read out in court, reflected what was intercepted by the gamma-zeta technique, was the message real.

The above is better.

Comment: The class size clause was indeed bargained. Not liking it now is irrelevant. Comment: I grew up Protestant, fully embracing my faith.  My boyfriend introduced me to his Catholic Church in 2002, and several years after we married, I joined the Catholic Church in 2008.  In the first few years, I had "all the zeal of a convert" as they say.  I felt guilt about abandoning my old tradition, so the idea that Catholicism was superior and right about everything helped to assuage that discomfort.  But as time went by, the imperfections of the Church as a human institution became impossible to ignore. I went through a faith crisis, became very angry and thought about leaving the Church.  I have come through the crisis with acceptance and resolution to be a witness to all the good and the bad in the Church.  The article's best line refers to the present tense, not the past tense.  I am still developing, we are all still developing, the Church is still developing.  The new converts, with all their political zeal, are still developing.  None are finished yet, all need patience.

Comment: The piece is at heart a pot stirrer, not a serious position.  While it does state some aspects of the discussion accurately, it is wildly off the mark on others and ignores an in place solution.  And the issue is not new, going back to the founding of Scouting.  In 1998 Scout Venturing was initiated, can and often is, coed which has the added benefit of youth learning to work together as they will find adult life - men and women in workplace and social contexts.  It serves those youth that want a different Scouting experience or one at all in the case of the girls. It also allows participation in Scouts to Age 21 vs to 18 Boy Scouts.  We had a Venture Crew associated with Boy Scout Troop 129 years ago; the same needs were true then and still are.  While the drama may make for good news filler, it's not at all valid.  Here is a link for those interested in the real story:   http://www.venturing.org/learn-more.html

Comment: Now hold on.  A flood plain can (and does) expand over time.  Every glacial river valley has change, everyday.  This river also has a wide swath that was noted by records of flooding dating back to Colony days, and further data when the railroad ran to Sutton.

Rivers change course,  they flood.  They meander.

Lastly, a 100 year flood plain is relative.  Nature does not deal with our empirical probabilities we place on it.  A 100 year flood plain can flood numerous times in that "return interval".  It can also happen two years in a row even.

Final answer: caveat emptor, and the old adage always reigns true: location, location, location.

Comment: The proliferation of the term "fake news" will ultimately do more harm to our society than any of the actual fake news out there.  You could see it in that embarrassment of a press conference, you can see it right in this comments section.

People need to realize that just because an article or opinion piece says something you don't personally agree with, does not make it "fake news".  Actual "fake news" is a kind of article alleging wildly unsubstantiated claims that have either been debunked, or have no possible method of verification.

So, please don't scream "Fake news!" anytime you read something you don't agree with. Actually think about what you are reading and the source.  You are allowed to not agree, but you shouldn't just immediately jump to these dangerous, and ultimately false conclusions.

Comment: They have a union contract.  Some affected players and their union officials had a meeting with Goodell/NFL and some club owners. No doubt negotiations went on, tho' they don't frame it in those terms. Goodell stated after the meeting there is no change in NFL policy about this, altho' he personally felt players should stand. Dershowitz should know that a union contract is a "game changer." Management can't do whatever it wants whenever it wants. There is language in the contract about what constitutes offenses that may merit discipline, such as suspension or termination. There are further nondiscrimination protections based, among other things, on race and participation in union activities (which, with official involvement now of the player's union, this has now become). Furthermore, all workers, union or not, are entitled under the National Labor Relations Act to "concerted activity" to protect and/or advance conditions of their work--and that includes disciplinary actions.

Comment: You -- and most others -- are confusing a single-payer funding mechanism with universal insurance coverage (let alone coverage without limitations). Single-payer by itself just means that the only insurance company is Government Insurance Corporation - not that Uncle Sam just willy-nilly pays for any cost a medical provider demands to cover anybody and everybody. (Health care is hard!)

E.g., Medicare is a single-payer system for the elderly. But that doesn't mean that Medicare pays for all the "sickies" or pays for every ailment (as any senior will testify to!). But, by being a single-payer for a broad group of users of the system Medicare can all but dictate costs to some degree and thereby limit expense while financing quality care.

Confusing these separate but intertwined aspects of health care just make it more difficult to address current shortcomings.

Comment: "Accopaniment?" No, you didn't get it right.

I take exception to the notion that Pope Francis is "very popular with the world." Yes, he has a certain popular appeal, but as it was with John Paul II, it's based more on personality than the substance of what he says and teaches. The world has no more use for his message of solidarity with the poor than it did for John Paul's teachings about the excesses of socialism and capitalism.

In point of fact, Francis strongly and consistently preaches "a challenging personal message of conversion." Some people just don't like that message because it calls to questions their preconceptions about such things as clericalism, triumphalism and mercy.

Most of us are in favor of conversion when others need it. But when it comes to what needs conversion within ourselves, not so much. Francis is no more and no less challenging that any previous pope. He's just focusing his challenges in a different direction and that rankles some.

Comment: Its easy to say "pay your workers", but many restaurants run on incredibly thin margins as it is.  Its a hard business to be in, and many places, even those that seem to be a hit with diners and critics, just can't make the math work and close their doors.  A "service included" model makes a lot of sense to me.  Charge what you need to charge to pay a reasonable wage to staff, and don't expect your guest to subsidize server wages off the books.  That prep cook or line cook will take home a bit more, and the service staff will get stability in their check based on hours worked.  No getting stiffed by a jerk of  a customer or having to ruthlessly upsell to try to max out the ticket price.  Its better for everyone, cook, buser, server, customer.

Comment: Timbuktu was a paved city in the 14th century already (along with many other advanced developments such as plumbing and flushing toilets) - it opened it's first major university in 1330. Under the leadership of the Mali king Masa Musa it became the wealthiest city in the world. Musa himself still holds the record for the wealthiest person in history. Adjusted for inflation - he could have bought out Bill Gates's entire fortune about 200 times over.

There is less concrete evidence of the British destruction - which is not surprising, after all they were doing specifically IN ORDER to keep secret what had been there. Advertising it would hardly have been conducive to such an exercise, but records do exist of the orders given. There are photographs of the city taken before the British began their settlement which shows it intact.

And please note: Timbuktu was not a rare case. Just an illustrative example of typical British behavior. Hell they did the SAME THING in the boer war !

Comment: I'd suggest documenting the interest of the surrounding neighborhood in keeping the park open with an online petition.  Then go back to the neighborhood board, presenting the petition and asking one more time. You WILL get an answer.  

If the answer you get is that the park is not lighted well enough or some other costly improvement,  you have two choices:  1.  Keep complaining until you get into the CIP budget, which could take years  and could be reset when a new mayor take office or 2. Raise the money yourself in the community by forming partnership with the City.  The City is currently working very hard to make this possible as the obstacle in the past has been a mountain of red tape.  Unless you are very well connected, this is not only fastest way but it is the only scenario where you have a say about project timing, quality of materials, and so on.

Comment: Not even close. Government is primarily there to defend and ensure individual rights and liberty, including economic liberty and protection of individuals' private property and effects from state scrutiny. National defense, some elements of infrastructure for the facilitation of commerce, and education (although not necessarily the actual delivery of that education) are also core functions, as well as a safety net of sorts for truly needy individuals. It establishes courts and law enforcement to referee disputes, without these entities unilaterally creating the rules of the game.

What government ought NOT do is dictate the terms of commerce, determine winners and losers in a free exchange of goods, services and labor for remuneration (hey, sometimes the "big guys" are in the right), and above all assume authority over local matters or the ability of free people to function on their own. That includes assuming that people are incapable of prioritizing and meeting their needs.

Comment: With National Popular Vote, all of the 270+ presidential electors from the enacting states will be supporters of the presidential candidate receiving the most popular votes in all 50 states (and DC)

With the current system of electing the President, none of the states requires that a presidential candidate receive anything more than the most popular votes in order to receive all of the state's or district’s electoral votes. 

Since 1828, one in six states have cast their Electoral College votes for a candidate who failed to win the support of 50 percent of voters in their state

Not a single legislative bill has been introduced in any state legislature in recent decades proposing to change the existing universal practice of the states to award electoral votes to the candidate who receives a plurality (as opposed to absolute majority) of the votes (statewide or district-wide). There is no evidence of any public sentiment in favor of imposing such a requirement.

Comment: If you watch sitcoms, Dad's are the butt of all jokes. There's no more Andy Griffith homespun wisdom or Ward Cleaver wry observations. In a time when deadbeat Dads are the norm, shouldn't the media celebrate REAL DADS?

Comment: The problem is belief-systems. Religion can be a positive influence when people understand that beliefs are myths that ring true on an emotional level. But, when people confuse myth and fact, the danger arises that those with one set of beliefs tend to think that those who do not share their belief system are deliberately obtuse and evil. We can engage in reasonable discussion about which religious myths help us to get along better and live more meaningful lives. And we can engage in discourse about what the world is really like by using the scientific method (that never discovers truth but is great at stopping ourselves from fooling ourselves). But when we assert as facts things that cannot be disproven (e.g.- Jesus literally rose from the dead), the only ways to settle the argument are to walk away or bash heads.    Our other problems (economic, political ) cause us to bash heads when belief systems differ.

Comment: As of 2014, there were 53,153 practicing male lawyers in Canada, but only 40, 920 practicing women, so there's 29% more men out their working as lawyers as there is women, at the moment.  Seeing as we've been graduating equal numbers of female graduates from law school for a shade over a decade, it's clear that we've equalized inputs to the system, and given enough time, older lawyers will retire and the field will equalize.

But, as of now ... how can any reasonable distribution of talent NOT produce more male appointees to judicial appointments?  How could historical appointments, when the ratio of working lawyers was even worse than it is now, not also do so?

And, more to the point of this article, how can the Justice Minister justify a lean significantly towards female judicial appointments when they make up a firm MINORITY of working lawyers?  Is our pool of female lawyers a statistical anomaly, and of higher quality than the men?

Comment: Pt. 2

"I like the mystery/God is closer to us by choice and out of love" - - yes, that's it, isn't it?  God is a mystery, but so loved us that He humbled Himself to take on a human nature out of love.  That is a mystery.  Certainly through the Incarnation God is close to us, and moreso, in a sense, when we receive His Body and Blood.  I think rather than mystery/otherness as something to be sought, many EF folks seek transcendance - - a sense of the holy and sacred which the quiet and contemplation of the EF fosters better for some people.   Another poster in the thread spoke of the Mass as feeling like a supper club (I know this is not your position), and for many, I think, it lacks a sense of the reverence appropriate to the Divine and to our Savior.  As in many Catholic things, it's both/and  God with us in the Incarnation and the Body and Blood, yet still retaining all of His Divine attributes wherein He is the creator and we are the creatures.  

Does that make sense?

Comment: I assume you're referring to the August 2017 20,000 acre Milli Fire.

One of my forestry associates lives in Sisters and we looked over the burn a month ago. At no time did he feel threatened, but the smoke was heavy and made the eclipse even more surreal.

More than fuel reduction and "thinning", it was the many private logging roads which were easily dozed into containment lines; the safe air space for fire retardant tankers, including huge VLTs; and the cooler, wet weather second week in September which "saved the town of Sisters", a full nine miles away.

Most of this fire burned through heavily cut over private forestlands, the big open grown, fire resistant ponderosa pines having been replaced, by default, with tightly packed flammable young lodgepole. Heavy logging slash from decade old operations didn't decompose in the dry eastside climate like it does in our part of the woods and further fueled this fire.

Worth a look!

Comment: Your complaint that these so-called (and unspecified) "warmists" use the less-than-formal term "settled" is a rather irrelevant bit centered around semantics. Again, yes, science is eternally subject to possible revision. But there is just about as much confidence in the core of AGW theory (an anthropogenically-enhanced "greenhouse" effect) as can possibly be had in science. Whether you call that "virtually certain" or "settled" doesn't really make a great deal of difference in that respect. It's quite real. The only failure in using the term "settled" is that it implies "over and done", and nothing in science is that.

You appear to be conflating "predicting the future" (modeling?) and AGW theory. The robustness of AGW theory rests on the traditional sciences and tens of decades of empirical evidence, not computer modeling. The reality is that the theory is quite certain, having withstood the challenge of countless scientists for well over 100 years. That's not PC, that's QED.

Comment: Haley lied when she said that the JCPOA “gave Iran what it wanted up-front, in exchange for temporary promises to deliver what we want.”  

-

The truth is that Iran had to fulfill most of its obligations first—including disposing of excess enriched uranium, disassembling enrichment cascades, gutting its heavy water reactor, and much else—before the agreement was fully implemented and Iran got even a whiff of additional sanctions relief.  

There is no correspondence between reality and Haley’s assertion that the agreement was a great deal for Iran but “what we get from the deal is much less clear.”  

What we get is a cementing closed (even literally, in the case of the disabling of a reactor that otherwise could have produced plutonium) of all possible pathways to an Iranian nuclear weapon.  

This isn’t just a promise; this is major, material, already implemented change.

http://tinyurl.com/y8wd9gyw

Read the whole thing.

Comment: Of course there is a sub-text. They are complaining about the numbers so clearly they think the 1 in 10 (and let's remember that other recent articles claimed 12% is 1-in-10 when it is in fact 1-in-8) is somehow the wrong number. Given the tone of the article it is fair to assume that they think the number should be higher. How is it to be higher? There are only a few possibilities:
1. The courts should convict more often.
2. The crown should lay charges more often.
3.  The police should refer cases to the crown more often.
They give no reason why any of these things should happen other than that women are making X complaints and only getting Y convictions. 
In fact they complain that only 1 in 10 offenders is convicted - the only way you can get "9 out of 10 offenders getting off " is if every complaint should result in a conviction.
In other words just what RKJ said - they are asking for more convictions based on nothing more than that a woman complained.

Comment: I still don't know if I would have supported the district had it made it to the ballot. But I think some would benefit from a little bit of fact-based thought.  I live in Elmira, about eight miles from Veneta. Veneta now contracts with the sheriff for a total of four deputies. Since Sheriff Trapp says it requires 5.2 FTE to assure 24/7 coverage (allowing for shift overlap, vacations, training, sick leave, other time away from patrol) Veneta actually has a little less than 24 hour coverage from one deputy seven days a week. That is roughly the same standard that is available in the county. However where I live, we have  three deputies providing coverage for the entire county (as observers noted about the size of Connecticut). Under the district proposal, my service would have increased substantially; the service in Veneta would have probably decreased, since the deputy on duty would have had a larger area to cover.

Comment: Years ago Anchorage began handing out tickets and fines to minors who were caught out after curfew.  My teenage daughter spent the night at a friend's house and I had to retrieve her from police custody at Service High School at 2:00 a.m.  All the kids were cited and the fine was substantial.  She had just opened her first checking account with a balance of over $600 of hard earned babysitting money.  We drove downtown and she wrote her first check ($250) to pay her fine.  The other kids' parents chose to get their kids off the hook. To this day, it feels like a knife to my heart when I think about my decision to choose tough love, but my daughter is so much the better for that experience.  She ended up graduating both high school and nursing school with honors, made the dean's list in college and she is a responsible and loved wife and mother today, with 3 children of her own.  I believe that young people must learn lessons early on if they are to reach their full potential in life.

Comment: There's nothing "Orwellian" about reminding lawyers we purportedly live in a democracy and equal justice for all is the major principle of a democratic society.
   Perversely, however, in Canada Inc., the majority of citizens cannot afford a lawyer. That means they cannot obtain justice. The poor and much of the middle class live at the mercy of upper middle class professionals and the wealthy.
  About once a year upper elitists of Canada's (in)justice system assuage their conscience with an unspecified call for less unequal justice. But hiring a lawyer in this increasingly authoritarian society and punitive economy remains increasingly out of reach for most Canadians.
   Why the majority of Canadians, denied compensation for a myriad of wrongs committed against them over the course of a lifetime, accept this undemocratic legal system, is beyond comprehension.
   Obviously the major thing Orwellian about the legal system is the old fascistic joke: some men are more equal than others.

Comment: Robert Harris apparently thinks that climate scientists lack his knowledge of earth's climate history.  Actually, they know from that history that rising atmospheric carbon correlates almost perfectly with global temperature rise.  Since the onset of industrialization, atmospheric carbon has increased by over 40%--a huge swing given the geologically insignificant time period. Carbox dioxide is a very long-lived greenhouse gas.  The excess carbon early coal-burning steam engines put in the air is still there.  Each year adds a new (and larger) increment--it's like filling a bathtub, not running a shower.  Earth temperatures in recent decades have risen correspondingly.  No plausible source for these short-term increases in carbon and heat, other than human greenhouse-gas producing activity, exists--at least, in the opinion of the vast majority of climate and earth scientists.  If Mr. Harris thinks they are wrong, perhaps he'll refer us to his peer-reviewed publications refuting them.

Comment: I believe there is an extremely relevant term.

at·tri·tion (əˈtriSH(ə)n) - the action or process of gradually reducing the strength or effectiveness of someone or something through sustained attack or pressure.

Lane Community College's goal is 100% elimination of classified employee union.  Over the past few years Lane Community College has been eliminating represented classified employees one at a time.  When  a permanent classified employee exits LCC, regardless of reason, they are replaced with part-time TEMPORARY employees.  A vacated full-time position usually gets replaced by two, sometimes three, temporary employees.  These temporary employees are restricted to 1040 hours of employment and do not receive any benefits.  When they reach 1039 hours they're terminated & told they must wait 6 months before they can re-apply.  LCC will simply wait until there are no more union members left.

Based on my own experiences I'm willing to bet outsourcing will next.

Comment: Our Hawaiian and Polynesian culture has, as one of its core cultural and social principles, the concept of malama aina which means "nurture and sustain what nurtures and sustains us" meaning the land and sea that provides for us.

This is a socio-cultural doctrine which establishes the collective kuleana (responsibility) of our people to care for the earth, the sea and the entire ecosystem of our planet so that it can nurture and sustain us in return. It mandates that we must take care of the natural world so that it can continue to function in perfect harmony and balance (pono) with man and with all of the organisms that exist in the natural world.

To accomplish this we take from nature only what we need to survive (subsistence) and leave no trace of our passing that may tend to upset the natural balance (sustainability). Polynesians and especially Hawaiians have been true stewards of the natural world thousands of years before it became a popular hipster fad in the western world.

Comment: Where ASD puts 200 teachers' jobs on the line and threatens to cut the cord? It's not a threat - it's a legal obligation.

The teachers have a contract. That contract has a provision whereby notice has to be given by a certain date if the position is not funded. Funding is dependent on legislative appropriation, and the House and Senate are far apart on what amount of funding they are willing to provide.

What would be irresponsible would be to let the layoff notice date pass without comment, then find themselves on the hook for all the teachers they are contracted to pay but with no funds to pay them.

If education were forward funded, then districts would only have to send out layoff notices to those teachers who they were certain would not be retained, but that's not the environment we live in.

Comment: Placing health care in the private sector would be a new vision and would control cost.

 It would mean that every Canadian who can pay their own way would pay their own way. From US data that would be about 83% of our population. That would mean only 17% rather than 100% of our population would be paid by the taxpayer. 

That massive saving could be used to cover those who cannot pay. 

Cost to Canadians who are paying would vary according to their wishes for coverage. I do wonder if the high cost of the US system is due to the massive amount of medical treatment required for people who have not had insurance (about 17%) and have not used the system until they were very sick. 

Since the private sector performs so well in every area where it is allowed to operate, I tend to put the US as a sample of one. Not a good example to base a system on. 

Do we want 1st or 2nd class

The US medical system is the best in the world. It may cost us to move to that level. Quality or 2nd class.

Comment: Good reminder, John. Canadians shouldn't touch U.S. MLPs with a ten foot pole - been there and got the T-shirt during my random, idea of the day investing days.

For people that are looking for robust yields from U.S. stocks I would suggest that they look at U.S. BDCs (business development companies) and U.S. mREITs (mortgage REITS). Higher average dividends than MLPs without any of the drawbacks.

Some suggested names to look at are:

BDCs - ARCC, MAIN, GSBD (piggy back on the big boys).
MREITs - AGNC, NLY, BXMT, STWD.

Disclosure - I own them all. But note these are not low risk stocks - dividends can fluctuate (driven by the fact that both have to pay out 90% of earnings each year) - but I would not characterise them as high risk either. I've held a bunch (7 REITs and 8 BDCs) for years  and have been fully satisfied with the performance.

Primarily yield plays - not going to see material capital appreciation.

Comment: Mr. Hanna, exactly how do you know who and what those who hang out downtown are? I don't know what you think goes on in Springfield, but courts have found no loitering ordinances to be illegal.  That is why we don't have such an ordinance in Eugene.  Likewise, panhandling cannot be banned in Eugene as it has been ruled to be free speech under the Oregon Constitution.

Day centers, more emergency shelter beds, more affordable housing, greatly expanded alcohol, drug, and mental health treatment services, job training and employment programs, are desperately needed.  Homelessness is a national crisis.

Comment: LW1: Amy's advice is (unfortunately) spot on. Your only option to legally "force" your mother to move would be if you could have her declared incompetent/unable to care for herself and a guardian appointed for her. Even if you are able to do so, are you willing to do that? It's a potentially long and emotionally wrenching process for everyone involved, and if you fail, I doubt your mom will feel the same about you or your sister. That said, the current situation might be worth it. Only you know how bad it really is.

An alternative would be to first try hiring a responsible home nurse or assistant for your mother, even part time, which would allow her to stay at home while providing her with support and taking some responsibilities off of you.

Comment: Kristin,
After reading your answers to the Herald Q&A, I still may vote for you, but feel the need to point out that you have your facts wrong about Lord Hill.  There are many studies that show the effect of mountain biking on wilderness is lower than the impact of equestrian use.  Simple reasons are 1- they are a thousand pounds lighter; 2- rolling impact is less than stepping; 3- bikers don't graze; and 4- bikes don't leave urine and poop on the trails.

Main reasons for mountain bike damage are unauthorized trails, so if you allow them to build in designated zones, there should be no need for additional trail building; and skidding, which again is mitigated by proper trail design.

Lord Hill is large enough to share, you can have your peaceful walks and we can bike 500 feet away, and you'll never know we are there or step in our shit.

2. Build with seismic upgrade: failed 5-3; Pryor, Syrett, Zelenka yes.
3. Build with private offices for councilors: failed 6-2; Brown, Taylor yes.
4. Build with "civic quality" in presented design: passed 6-2; Brown, Taylor no.
"Civic quality" refers to use of reclaimed western red cedar and overall look of building.

I hope this helps,

Christian Hill
Reporter, The Register-Guard

Comment: Times change. National parishes served a clearer purpose in the age of immigration and Irish hegemony in U. S. dioceses. I contrast Winsted, Connecticut, population about 7,000, with nearby , much larger Torrington. In Winsted, Catholics have worshiped at St. Joseph's, a Franciscan parish that united the diverse "ethnic" Catholics since 1852. For 33 years, Fr. Leo da Saracena led the parish with storied vigor, and he baptized Dad. In Torrington, the larger population created national parishes, one history of which is http://www.torringtoncatholics.org/about.html
Likewise, Catholics of the Eparchy of St. Maron of Brooklyn have a church on North Main Street, where we went sometimes when we were too late on the walk to St. Francis.
Many industries throughout Connecticut closed in the past forty years, and people drive off to other types of jobs.
Archbishop Blair is the thirteenth ordinary of Hartford. Two auxiliaries have Italian surnames. Most predecessors seem Irish.

This is NOT a story that should be swept under the rug.

Comment: Densification is at least partly to blame if it fails to deliver on its promises. It is clear from the disproportionate market value placed on detached homes that Canadians continue to value large, multi-bedroom dwellings that ideally would be affordable enough for families to live in. Densification has thus far provided a glut of luxury one bedroom condominiums which sell easily and profitably for developers but do nothing to meet the market demand for large affordable dwellings suitable for families. If government insists that they must distort the housing market significantly through policy, they could at least make better efforts at incentivizing building the kind of homes that actually meet market requirements--i.e. affordable multi-bedroom dwellings, whether it is larger condominiums or "missing middle" alternatives such as split-level homes, townhouses, etc.

The civil war in Syria will end soon - as soon as Donald Trump strikes his alliance with Russia to end it -  and I believe at that point most Syrians will want to go back.

Comment: A tax regime patterned on BC's is no Panacea.

First, it is very easy to circumvent the BC tax. A numbered company with a BC resident lawyer the named representative (and you with the hidden beneficial interest) will do the trick and this is only one of many dodges. 

Second, the tax is a one-time cost at the time of purchase and does nothing to prevent the property remaining vacant, to generate any surtax revenue thereafter or to otherwise preserve the vitality of the city.

Third, the tax is open to challenge under NAFTA and other international free trade agreements because it subjects citizens of our trade partners to burdens not imposed on Canadians.

Try an annual tax of .5% of a residential property's assessed value for municipal tax purposes where the property is not occupied as attested in a sworn document for 7 or more months in the preceding year by an individual who is the owner, a member of the owner's immediate family, a director or employee of the owner company, etc.

Comment: B.C has always been a strange political landscape. No one party can be considered to be dominant in the province. In Alberta, the conservatives have always enjoyed majority support (with small exceptions like now). Ditto in Saskatchewan Ontario has always been liberal country with a few one-term conservative intervals.

But in B.C, it all depends on where you are in the province. The lower mainland and Southern Vancouver island are owned by the NDP, while the interior region and North part of the province belong to the conservatives/liberals. To make it even more confusing, there are different levels of support for different parties depending on what community or district you live in. All this makes B.C the most difficult province to predict elections, and of course it can lead to deadlocks like the one we are witnessing now.

Comment: Dear Mr. Morneau

I am a high-tech entrepreneur & small business owner responsible for creating numerous well-paying jobs, etc.

I am a high income earner and not "taxed at a much lower rate than everyone else" and I do not "use a corporate structure to reduce my personal taxes". In fact, I pay more than half my earnings (53%) in income tax alone.

The "average" Canadian now pays more in taxes (income tax, sales tax, fuel tax, carbon tax, etc.) than they do for the "essentials" of life (food, shelter, clothes, etc.)

The problem with our taxation system and our economy is not the top 10% of earners avoiding taxes (they currently pay more than 50% of all income tax while the bottom 50% pay virtually no income tax) - the real problem is TOO MUCH TAX for all Canadians. 

This is the real "unsustainable" problem and the cause is not a surplus of private corporations; but rather a surplus of government spending - ie. a bloated, overpaid public sector with pensions, benefits, etc.

Comment: In theory, homework makes sense because it extends learning and teaches self-control and initiative. Unfortunately, this works only for those students who have a supportive home environment. 
Homes differ. Some parents expect their child to complete homework and provide a supportive place and time to do it. At the other extreme are homes that are chaotic, sometimes due to drug use, lack of parenting skills or because parents are absent, working two or more jobs. These are not excused for good parenting. They are conditions that children cannot control. 
Is it reasonable to impact the child's success with conditions not under their control? If teachers are responsible for learning in the class, then can we make parents responsible for learning at home? 
If the school provides a place after hours to do additional study and offers homework as additional credit, I have no concerns. Otherwise, homework disadvantages some children for things they cannot control.

Comment: Yes.

Generally speaking, you want to avoid the possibility of having any software run on your system without you actively choosing for it to. When using web browsers, the best practice is to disable all client-side scripting (which does exactly this) by default, and only allow specific instances on a case-by-case basis. This includes Java, Javascript (which as you point out is less dangerous than Java), VBScript, JScript, and others. This stuff can get a bit tricky for the layman, though. My general recommendation is to run a combo such as Firefox with the NoScript plugin.

A good firewall is essential, yes, and IE is not the security disaster that is used to be -- but no browser should be considered "secure".

All that said, in my experience few ordinary users are willing to put up with the inconvenience of actually having good security. That's one of the reasons that I emphasize backups, so at least people can recover if it all goes south.

Comment: In a socialist country, Norway; In 2009, the total tax revenue was 41.0% of the gross domestic product (GDP). Of the OECD member countries Denmark, Sweden, Belgium, Italy, France, Finland and Austria had a higher tax level than Norway in 2009. The tax level in Norway has fluctuated between 40 and 45% of GDP since the 1970s.[6]

The relatively high tax level is a result of the large Norwegian welfare state. Most of the tax revenue is spent on public services such as health services, the operation of hospitals, education and transportation.[7]

Revenue levels are also influenced by the important role played by oil and gas extraction in the Norwegian economy.

Comment: From the article: "In the minus column, he isn’t well known outside his home province,"
========

That is an understatement.  Even in Ontario he isn't all that well known, being the deputy leader of the 3rd place party and one who only came into Provincial politics a bit over 5 years ago.  It is really only after the 2014 Ontario election, when his name was being tossed around as a potential leader for the Ontario NDP following Horwath's disappointing performance, that he started getting some recognition here.

That being said he does seem to tick off all the right boxes for a good leader of the NDP.  He is charismatic and well spoken.  He can connect well to youth (and isn't all that old himself) and has been pushing for all the right kind of causes to get people to support him.

He might well be the best NDP candidate so far, though I'm still not sure that it's enough to propel them beyond 3rd party status?  I'm not so sure.

Second, I would refer them to pray over those passages where Jesus grants full authority to his Church, suggesting that therefore, we the Church today have the same authority that Paul exercised in his day.

Third, I would invite them to pray over the two passages in the Gospels where Jesus takes a stance against divorce. I would refer them to commentaries that point out that in one of these passages, Jesus allowed an exception in the case of adultery, whereas in the other there is no such exception in the text read literally. 

I would then invite them to note that on the basis of these two passages as different strands of the Christian Tradition have developed different canonical positions. Protestants in general accept divorce, building on the adultery exception in one Gospel and Paul's override of Jesus dictate. Orthodoxy completely rejects divorce, but when it happens, when marriages irretrievably break down, out of God's mercy it allow a second and even a third marriage.

Comment: The problem, of course, is that the British parliamentary system, which is the basis of our governance structure, is grounded in the philosophy of the "supremacy of parliament." This isn't an insignificant consideration. We've overlaid our governance structure with the Charter, which is an American-style attempt to balance the division of powers, and in particular to give much more power to the judiciary than was previously the case in Canada. Is this is good development? Personally, I think it's generally worked, however, the notwithstanding clause does serve to provide a means to enforce the public interest and the public good. Without it, Quebec would probably have left the federation. And more recently, Saskatchewan has talked about using it to protect the interests of students to attend Catholic schools where rural public schools shut down and the available alternatives are distant. The basis for using the clause should always be the demonstrable protection of the public interest.

Comment: I'm disappointed, I take the bus everyday from Fairview (next to the Senior Center) to the University, and my route has been axed. With the new system, it looks as though I would have to take 2, possibly 3, buses, plus additional walking time...in short, it will most likely be as quick or quicker to walk to school. I'm a bit surprised that there appears to be only one route going to the University now - if any young people were going to use the bus system, it would be students. I have never had an issue with the frequency of the buses - the 13 route is once an hour (I think an extra one comes around between 8 and 9am). I don't really see how this system is better if it potentially involves more walking, especially in a cold-climate city like Anchorage. I also just think that more walking would discourage people in general. Ideally, it would encourage people to get out and exercise, realistically, it will discourage people form taking the bus, possibly killing the system altogether.

Comment: Yes, but the author is still committing the (deliberate?) error of implying that opportunity is merely a proxy for outcome. So that if the schools in your area are worse than those in mine, you must be subsidised in some way to make up the difference. 

This is the kind of definition-conflation typical of a modern liberal arts education. 

So Teresa invokes the core problem: since we are all born with different abilities, our outcomes are bound to be different *even or especially* given equal opportunity, when equal opportunity is understood to mean that there is no external force ACTIVELY LIMITING us during our lives.

e.g. there is no "national-socialist" government preventing us contracting with each other, nor any modern "social-democratic" government intervening in our contract to promote "equity". 

True equality of opportunity may well be impossible in a democracy in the long run. The U.S. probably got closest, between 230 and 100 years ago.

Comment: The fluoride compound that is added to water by municipalities is a silicofluoride, which never occurs naturally in nature and has been shown to be 85 times more toxic than naturally occurring calcium fluoride. These silicofluorides are actually a hazardous waste, a by-product of industrial procedures, containing many toxic pollutants. Although they have been approved by some as a "medical treatment," for every study "proving" their benefit, there are two others "proving" their toxicity and dangers. Not all that is presented as "science" is accurate or honest. Some studies are nefarious. For this reason alone, it is right and ethical to allow the public to think for themselves, to research for themselves, and to govern what "medications" are personally ingested. Water is a fundamental resource necessary for everyone's survival. Silicofluorides are not. They are, in fact, a hazardous waste. It is unethical to mix the two under the premise that it is "for the common good."

My fault clearly. It's obvious now I simply 'misunderstood' the 'format'.  I was foolish to say it was erratic and selective - not stopping to think for a second it might be 'nonlinear'. Who knew? We're also told it's not meant to be definitive. It's just one version of what happened or might have happened - at least from an Upper Canadian perspective. Comment: Larry:  you keep repeating the nonsense that Powell's e-mail account was somehow secured "by appropriate government agencies".  It's not true - he had a commercial account the equivalent of GCI.net.  It was NOT "authorized by the State Department" or " "secured by government agencies" AND he deleted ALL of his e-mails.  E-mails that he used to daily communicate with ambassadors, subordinates and foreign ministers.  Who knows what was in them?  At least Clinton retained and turned over her e-mails.  The only reason any of Powell's e-mails were ever found is because some were sent to subordinates on the department's e-mail system.  When the Department's OIG says that Powell "cooperated" with their investigation, it means that he agreed to be interviewed - not that he turned over any e-mails.  This is clearly stated in the IG report.  It's also false to say that Clinton did not cooperate in any way.  She didn't agree to be interviewed - but she DID turn over her e-mails - unlike Powell.

Comment: Helfrich was paid less this year than Kelly made in his last year at Oregon. Kelly's six-year deal had him making $4 million in 2015 and 2016. Helfrich's maxed out at $3.85 million in 2019. Both coaches held the job for four years; both coached in and lost national-title games. Both won a Rose Bowl.

Helfrich, who made $2 million during the 2014 title run, was a bargain by comparison. No one complained about Kelly's compensation. Winning mutes that.

Also, Helfrich is obligated contractually to mitigate the buyout liquidation by making a reasonable effort to seek comparable employment. If he finds another job paying half as much, Oregon is on the hook for the other half. His contract is readily available online for perusal.

Comment: I am pointing out that as our spending habits change, it makes it harder for a young family to save money.  My family lectured me about the starving children in Africa when I complained about the food on my plate that I didn't like, because my grandparents came to this country as penniless immigrants, and my parents were raised through the Great Depression and WWII rationing. It made them frugal, and happy with little, which made it easier to save from even meager salaries.
I came from a single mother family, and I do know that if you clean up your debts, live on a budget, and only buy what's necessary, you can put that money away.I have a Master's degree and never borrowed for college, even with a wife and a baby. And building that habit into your lifestyle will mean you're still putting away money later.  I packed my lunch today with leftovers, as I've done for 40+ years.  I eat from Tupperware, but I have a retirement account and a nice home.  Wonder if there's a connection there...

Comment: That was the quandary I had when working downtown in the 80's/90's.  The express bus was pretty comfortable and convenient from the PnR (actually far more comfortable than the train).  So I usually took it to avoid parking costs (it was about a wash on cost). But it took an hour from home to work, whereas driving took about 35-40 minutes.  

I remember looking at the Fastracks map about 5 years ago, when I lived in the mountains up from Golden. I thought that it might eventually be worth using it to get to DIA.  As soon as I saw the travel times I quickly dismissed that thought (90 minutes vs 45 driving).

Ridership in any city will be far higher during morning/even commutes, of course. But I think RTD will continue to struggle with just a small trickle of off-peak usage (excluding the airport line) for many years to come in this metro. Especially on the R-line that doesn't have the parking savings incentive. Driving is just the better option for most people.

Comment: Your analogy is flawed - apples and orangutans.  This is an individual who has been found to have had his charter rights breached by government action and inaction.  

It is not a case alleging a law is unconstitutional and dealt with under the remedy at s. 52(1).

If an individual's Charter rights have been breached there are broad remedies available - see s.24(1).  The section says if an individual's rights are breached he/she can "obtain such remedy as the court considers appropriate and just in the circumstances" and in this case the remedy is an award of damages.

S. 24(1) must be distinguished from s 52(1) of the Constitution Act, 1982. Whereas section 52 allows the courts to invalidate laws or parts of laws for breaches of the constitution (including the Charter), section 24 has broader capabilities.  That was the situation in the prostitution case where s. 52(1) was applied.

Comment: Far too many people have a concept of retirement that is a leftover from 3 or more decades ago when life expectancies were shorter and the retirement age was 65.

It is simply the case that much has changed. 

Retirement savings, including Pension  Plans, RRSPs, Group RRSP's and TFSAs, are now about creating choices. 
A choice to retire younger, or not, will be influenced by your financial where with all.
A choice to semi-retire or change to a different job is quite common now.

I work in the retirement business. Over my thirty plus years of doing so, the change is immense and mostly healthy.

Working 40 or more years followed by a few years of sitting back and then dying is not at all the goal now.

People want to enjoy life to the fullest before, during , and after their careers end.

500 years ago, retirement was not even a concept. Our recent concepts about work and life are the aberration.

"The current scientific consensus places the worldwide polar bear population between 20,000 and 25,000 animals. Comment: That's what I'm saying, that we're moving it when we pump it from the aquifer.  Some goes into the plants and/or evaporates, but doesn't the majority simply go into the soil when they irrigate?  The plants suck up some of it from the soil but I doubt they suck up all or even most of it.  Although I suppose much of what stays in the soil eventually evaporates into the air as well.

Then there's the question of where does the water that evaporates in Colorado end up? Does the jet stream tend to carry it out of state before it usually comes back down in the form of rain?

Again, just curious questions.  My main point is that it would be more educational to couch the discussion in terms of the RELOCATION/RECYCLING of water than "using it up", since the water doesn't actually cease to exist.  It just gets moved around.

Comment: As Inauguration Day gets closer, I've been thinking a lot about how I want to face the next four years. Do I intend to spend my days reacting to whatever the Trump administration is doing at any given moment, letting my temperament be jostled by events beyond my control? Or will I choose to do what I can, which is to be a peacemaker where I'm planted?

I think sometimes we focus on mega-political and religious issues because they distract us from doing our own personal soul-maintenance. At least, I know that to be true of myself. It's easy to project the causes for problems onto other people, other political parties, other religions, etc. It's much tougher to take personal ownership of my own complicity.

With that in mind, I'm taking a break from this site so as to spend less time addressing heat and more seeking light. I wish everybody God's peace.

Comment: So, if a skeptical friend hits you with the "saturation argument" against global warming, here’s all you need to say: (a) You’d still get an increase in greenhouse warming even if the atmosphere were saturated, because it’s the absorption in the thin upper atmosphere (which is unsaturated) that counts (b) It’s not even true that the atmosphere is actually saturated with respect to absorption by CO2, (c) Water vapor doesn’t overwhelm the effects of CO2 because there’s little water vapor in the high, cold regions from which infrared escapes, and at the low pressures there water vapor absorption is like a leaky sieve, which would let a lot more radiation through were it not for CO2, and (d) These issues were satisfactorily addressed by physicists 50 years ago, and the necessary physics is included in all climate models.

http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2007/06/a-saturated-gassy-argument

Comment: Increasing diversification reduces specific risk, but you're more likely to be increasing your exposure to broad systemic risk. It's like the idea of an MBS. Diversification was the argument underpinning that: buy a portfolio of a ton of mortgages and you'll never have to worry about the quality of any individual mortgage. But when the housing market collapses systemically, you're toast. Alternative to the MBS, you could buy select high quality mortgages, where you may not have the same systemic risk (though now your skill is in question). 

But at the end of the day, indexes or broad portfolios are all about individuals in aggregate, and quality does matter. You can pretend it doesn't, and that's the mainstream advice these days. And perhaps this ignorance even makes sense, as few managers have proven capable of outperforming sheer ignorance. But it is an ignorant view. Indexing is buying garbage, it's assured. You're just hoping the garbage is specific and not systemic.

Comment: The minimum wage is indeed controversial.

But please note that the economists supporting the increase are not what most would call "liberal economists".    

The vast majority of "liberal economists" that I have known over the years -- and that includes a lot of heavy hitters -- are either against major increases in minimum wages or at the very least very wary of sharp increases to minimum wages.  

As a group, "liberal economists" tend to prefer guaranteed annual incomes or negative incomes taxes in order to support low-income workers.  

Perhaps those concerned about low-income workers should think about the labour supply picture.  Canada's immigration policy continues to welcome large numbers of uneducated, unskilled immigrants.   That will enhance competition for low-wage employment in regional labour markets.

The solution would be either a greater emphasis on merit criteria or simply a slower flow of net immigration.

Comment: There's a problem here with leadership. It's reactive rather than pre-emptive.

There's a story I love from Formula 1 racing. It goes back to 1997 where the Williams team won the championship in the controversial last race of the year. Amongst the controversies was what amounted to wire tapping by the Ferrari team - a practice that had long been suspected but which was now confirmed.

It was put to one of the Williams engineers that they might have done the same if the boot were on the other foot. He said no, Sir Frank Williams calls the team management in at the start of every season and tells them what his team will not do. It doesn't matter if others do it and prosper, the Williams team does not do these things.

That's leadership. 

Too often these days - in business and in politics - leadership is reactive. They don't draw a pre-emptive line, they react when something happens and try to talk their way out of it.

Comment: She's quoted in one story on-line as saying she attributed her longevity to good genes and eating two raw eggs per day.

She could well have been right.   Eggs are the perfect food and if not overcooked (the yolk needs to be runny -- or raw, essentially), they are a great source of both active forms of vitamin B12.   Both forms are crucial to achieve longevity.   The other vitamin she must have got from eggs and eating other grass-fed animal proteins is vitamin K2, without which she would have had problems with fragile bones and artheriosclerosis.   

Interestingly, most North Americans are deficient in vitamin K2, and so we have lost of osteoporosis and heart problems.    Vitamin B12 deficiency (particularly adenosylcobalamin) is a major issue worldwide, especially for vegetarians and vegans.

She probably had a very good basic metabolism (based on genetics) and a source of very nutritious eggs from a farm or someone who raised chickens on a varied diet.

Comment: Once again Krugman turns an important matter into a partisan issue.  Trumpcare?  Krugman is supposed to be smart.  But nowhere in this polemic is there a serious discussion of the underlying barriers to good universal health care.  IMHO, we can never achieve good universal care with the medical industry as currently formulated.  This is not about Obamacare, Trumpcare, etc.  This is about medical costs and limitations on the supply of medical service.  The medical industry is incredibly powerful.  We cannot prevail to restructure it on a partisan basis.  To fix health care and provide good universal coverage, we, all Americans, regardless of party must undertake a very difficult task of controlling a massively powerful special interest.  We need either single payer with strong cost control, or nationalized medicine.  We can achieve these objectives only if all of us Americans regardless of party join together to make it happen.  If 60% or so of us make the issue #1, we can do it.

Comment: Plates mounded with cheap shrimp float on a veritable sea of ecological and social trouble. In his excellent 2008 book Bottomfeeder: How to Eat Ethically in a World of Vanishing Seafood, the Canadian journalist Taras Grescoe took a hard look at the Asian operations that supply shrimp. His conclusion: "The simple fact is, if you're eating cheap shrimp today, it almost certainly comes from a turbid, pesticide- and antibiotic-filled, virus-laden pond in the tropical climes of one of the world's poorest nations..."  A recent study in Thailand by Swedish-based scientists found that 77 percent of bacteria in farmed shrimp were resistant to one or more antibiotics.

Comment: There is a danger in the idea that we are our body, that our body (or actually our self-reports or feelings of our body) always points to the good and the true.

Not so.

Anorexics rely on their self-reports.  And they're horrifically wrong. 

Some people have relied on "self-reports" of their body & gotten a sex change operation, but have decided in later years to reverse it!

So discerning the truth and the good takes work; it doesn't simply come "naturally".  We can get it wrong.

Our body is given to us to master, to develop, to use, to put to God's work. 

We often have to temper our feelings, our self-reports of our body.."no, you don't need more booze, chow, sex in the middle of the subway."

We have to temper some (what our emotions might insist as) "cravings" of our body.

We have to sometimes push our body around in order to serve the good. Tell it who is the boss. 

The body is not the boss.

The "why of my body" often has less to do with "my body" than it does my soul.

Comment: Here is the reality:

Does this dinner and the previous fundraiser breach Trudeau's rules on "Open and transparent" Govt?    Answer:  yes.

Does this make the Liberal Govt look like blatant hypocrites?   Answer:  yes.

Does this violate any existing conflict of interest or election laws?   Answer: no.


This should hurt the Liberals and rightly so, but it only serves (again) to show how our party fundraising rules need a major reset.

I would like to see election financing be fixed and fundraising outlawed.    At the very least, eliminate ALL tax credits for political donations.     These credits force every Canadian to support every donation (up to 75% of the donation).

Some formula of fixed subsidy and per vote subsidy would be far better.   And issue each candidate a wooden soapbox and a megaphone.

Of course, that would still leave the problem of block votes for access, which is used by groups led by McVety, etc.
